(2) Getting APIs to Work



API Kingdoms: API Interaction Patterns

API Kingdoms: API Interaction Patterns Erik Wilde (@dret): Beyond Pet Tech: Picking the Right Style for your API Product

(4) Synchronous: Getting in Line

  • Interaction pattern of approaching a counter
  • No tight coupling beyond individual transactions
  • Workflows supported by providing service affordances
  • Dominating pattern for partner/public APIs


API Kingdoms: API Interaction Patterns Erik Wilde (@dret): Beyond Pet Tech: Picking the Right Style for your API Product

(5) Asynchronous: Fire and Forget

  • Interaction pattern of receiving a message/call
  • Workflows are harder to support/represent
  • Increasingly popularity for private APIs

Tunnel Style Erik Wilde (@dret): Beyond Pet Tech: Picking the Right Style for your API Product

(8) One Tunnel to Call them All



Tunnel Style Erik Wilde (@dret): Beyond Pet Tech: Picking the Right Style for your API Product

(9) Distributed Programming

  • Distribution and Decentralization are two distinct patterns
  • Rooted in Remote Procedure Call (RPC) approaches of the 1980s
  • Functions are the main abstraction calls are tunneled to the server
  • A good fit for developers looking to write a distributed program

Resource Style Erik Wilde (@dret): Beyond Pet Tech: Picking the Right Style for your API Product

(11) Listing All Resources



Resource Style Erik Wilde (@dret): Beyond Pet Tech: Picking the Right Style for your API Product

(12) Identifiers for Resources

  • Providing globally identified resources that support interactions
  • Resources ideally are defined through a user-centric design process
  • API Stories help explaining how to walk across resources

Hypermedia Style Erik Wilde (@dret): Beyond Pet Tech: Picking the Right Style for your API Product

(14) Linking All Resources



Hypermedia Style Erik Wilde (@dret): Beyond Pet Tech: Picking the Right Style for your API Product

(15) Hypermedia APIs

  • Resources contain hypermedia controls for next steps
  • Workflows are designed into the API
  • Hypermedia API landscapes fell like one huge API
  • Developers can have a hard time letting go of controlling the flow

Query Style Erik Wilde (@dret): Beyond Pet Tech: Picking the Right Style for your API Product

(17) Querying into Server-Side Models



Query Style Erik Wilde (@dret): Beyond Pet Tech: Picking the Right Style for your API Product

(18) Querying Structured Data

  • Good for APIs with a vast interconnected data space
  • APIs are based on a generic data model and matching query language
  • Challenging learning curve for complex data models
  • Change management and security are non-trivial

Event-Based Style Erik Wilde (@dret): Beyond Pet Tech: Picking the Right Style for your API Product

(20) Event Publish/Subscribe



Event-Based Style Erik Wilde (@dret): Beyond Pet Tech: Picking the Right Style for your API Product

(21) Reversing Control

  • Good fit when actions originate on the server
  • Requires an event fabric to deliver events to consumers
  • Big range of models from per API to Event Service Bus (ESB)
  • Used more for private than for partner/public APIs


API Technologies: Embrace Diversity

Outline (API Technologies: Embrace Diversity)

  1. API Kingdoms: API Interaction Patterns [2]

API Technologies: Embrace Diversity Erik Wilde (@dret): Beyond Pet Tech: Picking the Right Style for your API Product

(23) There Cannot Be Only One

  • Growing and evolving API landscapes are the new normal
  • Deciding on the one API style/technology/platform is a losing battle
  • Plan and architect for diversity
  • There is a broad spectrum between The One and Anything Goes


API Technologies: Embrace Diversity Erik Wilde (@dret): Beyond Pet Tech: Picking the Right Style for your API Product

(24) Pick the Right Tool for the Job

  • APIs are used for many different things
  • There is no single style/tech that's solving all problems (well)
  • Always start with the customer and their needs
  • Manage your toolset as part of API governance


Conclusions

Outline (Conclusions)

  1. API Kingdoms: API Interaction Patterns [2]

Conclusions Erik Wilde (@dret): Beyond Pet Tech: Picking the Right Style for your API Product

(26) Serve the Business Need

  • APIs are languages to get jobs done
  • Understand the language families out there
  • Pick the right family and technology for your API job


Conclusions Erik Wilde (@dret): Beyond Pet Tech: Picking the Right Style for your API Product

(27) Thank You!
